name: Paro
description: Home to the iconic Tiger's Nest Monastery, Paro is Bhutan's cultural and historical gem nestled in a lush valley.

placesToVisit.name: Taktshang Monastery (Temple)
placesToVisit.description:
Taktshang Monastery is also known as Tiger Nest. The most famous landmark, Taktshang Monastery (Tiger Nest), stands on a granite cliff about 1000 m above the valley. It admitted that Guru Rinpoche, a famous Buddhist saint, flew to Paro on a tigress and meditated at Taktshang. Taktshang monastery is recognising as being a national treasure of Bhutan.
Depending upon your fitness, it will take about 1.5 hours to reach the viewpoint, and from there, you will experience a spectacular view of the monastery clinging to the side of the cliff. Then hike further up to the monastery which will take about 1 hour. After visiting the Taktshang monastery, stop for lunch at the viewpoint cafeteria and then walk further downhill to the road point.

placesToVisit.name: Tachog Lhakhang (temple)
placesToVisit.description: This 15th-century temple situated at the base of a mountain across the Pa Chu on the Paro- Thimphu highway. The only way to approach the Tachog Lhakhang is on foot, over the newly constructed cantilever bridge. In the 14th century, a renowned bridge builder named Duthob Thangtong Gyalpo had built Tachog Lhakhang (Temple). It houses the relics of the temple such as Guru Rinpoche, a statue of Lord Buddha Sakyamuni, a set of Kanjur (the translated words of Buddha) and Tenjur (the translated commentaries on word of Buddha), Chenrezig, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal, Chana Dorji, Thugse Dewa Zangpo and walking sticks of Thangtong Gyalpo.

placesToVisit.name: Chuzom
placesToVisit.description: It is the confluence of Pa Chu- the river flowing through Paro valley & Wangchu-the river flowing through Thimphu valley. Chuzom is also a major road junction with the south road to Phuntsholing, northeast to Thimphu and southwest road leading to Haa district. Bhutanese traditions regard such a union of rivers as inauspicious, and there are three Chortens (stupa) here to ward off evil spells in this particular area. Each Chorten (stupa) is in a different style (Bhutanese, Tibetan and Nepali). You can stop to enjoy the beauty of Chuzom and to take the photographs.

placesToVisit.name: Ta Dzong (National Museum of Paro)
placesToVisit.description: Perched above Paro Dzong was built as a watchtower in 1649, which now houses National Museum of Bhutan. Today this museum houses the best collections of all time historical items like antique Thangkha paintings, textiles, weapons & household objects making worth for a visit.

placesToVisit.name: Rinpung Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Fortress on a Heap of Jewels- is ranked one of the best Bhutanese architecture. The massive buttressed walls that tower over the town are visible throughout the valley, especially when landing at Paro Airport. The Dzong also offers the administrative seat of the district of Paro. The Dzong was built-in 1644 under the order of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. The spring Paro Tshechu held in this courtyard of Rinpung Dzong. The views from the windows are breath-taking.

placesToVisit.name: Nya Mey Zam Bridge
placesToVisit.description: It is a traditional covered cantilever bridge connecting the Paro town. Local people believe it is ill omen if one sees a fish in the river. The earlier bridge which could fold during the war was washed away by the flood in 1969.

placesToVisit.name: Kichu Lhakhang (Temple)
placesToVisit.description:
Kichu Lhakhang can reach within a ten-minute drive from Paro town; it is in the Lango Gewog. The temple is one of the oldest temples to have been built in Bhutan. In the 7th century, the Tibetan King Songtsen Gampo had built 108 temples in a day throughout the Himalayan regions, and Kichu Temple is one of them. 
The temple has many relics which date from the 7th century being one of the oldest temples in Bhutan. It houses oldest statues of Lord Buddha Sakyamuni, and two of his disciples i.e. Sharibu (Sariputra), Mangalbu (Maudgalyana) and other relics that has been added in the Jokhang.

placesToVisit.name: Traditional Hot Stone Bath
placesToVisit.description: It is very nice to experience Bhutanese hot stone bath.  It is the perfect way to relax and wind down after a long day of sightseeing, and it considered for numerous health benefits. It admitted that the local herbs all combine to produce medicinal benefits for joint pains, hypertension, stomach disorders and arthritis.

placesToVisit.name: Chele La Pass
placesToVisit.description: It is highest motor-able road passes connecting two districts Paro and Haa, an elevation of 3988m above the sea level. On clear days, the Chele la pass provides stunning views of the sacred enjoy sacred Mt. Jomolhari (7314m). The Chele-la pass is marked by hundreds of prayer flags fluttering in the wind. The top of the pass bloom with rhododendrons in a variety of colours-pale pink, deep pink, white and burnt orange, in season. You can also plan to ride mountain biking from Pass to Paro valley with a stretch of 36-48km, mostly downhill and comfortable ride.

placesToVisit.name: Paro Airport View Point
placesToVisit.description: Paro Airport viewpoint is about 10-minute drive from the airport gate or Paro town. It situated on the hill overlooking the airport; this viewpoint offers the best view of the whole airport, many sacred sites and historical monuments. The viewpoint mark above the airport is the best place to watch planes landing and taking off. It strongly recommended making a detour here when you arrive in Bhutan or when you're just driving to catch your flight.

placesToVisit.name: Kila Goemba Nunnery
placesToVisit.description: Kila Goemba located below Chelela pass on the road to Haa Valley which is far away from the hustle and bustle of the towns. It is around 27km from Bondey, Paro. Kila Goemba Nunnery is also known as Chele la Gompa which is home to 100 nuns. There are seven small temples and retreat huts built on the Cliffside facing Paro. On a clear day, you can see the spectacular view of Jele Dzong, Paro Valley, Mt.Jomolhari and Jichu Drake. The hike up from the roadside takes around an hour each way through steep slopes and forest.

placesToVisit.name: Paro Weekend Market
placesToVisit.description: Paro weekend market is lively during the weekend. The market has small stalls and big shops selling the product at the best prices. The market offers a fashionable product. You will get authentic Bhutanese handicrafts, traditional boots and other souvenirs at the reasonable price.

placesToVisit.name: Namgay Artisanal Brewery
placesToVisit.description: Namgay Artisanal Brewery located at Dumsibu, Paro. In Namgay Brewery they brew six types of beer and Apple cider in their brewery. The brewery offers Apple Cider and six variants of beer namely craft beers, red rice lagers, pilsners, pale and dark ales, milk stout and wheat beer to suit the different palates. The Bhutanese ingredients make the beer more enjoyable than ever before, with the unique local taste.

placesToVisit.name: Dungtse Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Dungtse Lhakhang located just next to the town and it is a five-minute drive from town. The three-storied Chorten-shaped temple was built in 1433 by the great bridge-builder Thangtong Gyalpo. Dungtse Lhakhang builds on the head of demons, which was causing illness to the inhabitants. The temple is unique in Bhutan as its paintings show the progressive stages of Tantric Buddhist philosophy. It houses relics in the temple such as two statues of the founder himself, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel, Chana Dorji, Guru Rimpoche, Milarepa, the future Buddha Jowo Jampa and two statues of Lord Buddha Sakyamuni.

placesToVisit.name: Drukgyel Dzong
placesToVisit.description: It is situated 14km north of Paro town. Drukgyel Dzong or The Fortress of the Victorious Bhutanese is one of the oldest Dzong in Bhutan. The Dzong was constructed in 1646 by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal to commemorate the victory of the Bhutanese over the Tibetan and Mongolian armies. The Dzong was served solely for defensive purpose without religious functions and administrative due to threats from the border. The name of the Dzong Druk (is the local name for Bhutan), while Gyel refers to victory that is why it is known as the fortress of victory. The fort was destroyed by fire in 1951, the ruins remain impressive sightseeing, and one will enjoy the views from the top of the hill. Currently, only the ruins of charred gigantic wooden posts, beams and watchtowers, giant walls can see which an important fortress that repelled several invasions was once.

placesToVisit.name: Dzongdrakha Gompa
placesToVisit.description: Dzongdrakha Gompa is also referred to as mini Taktshang due to its unique location on a cliff above Bondey village. The temples of Dzongdrakha Gompa were built in the 16th century. Four temples dedicated to Tsheringma, Guru, Buddhist deity Tara and Jowo Jampa. It believed that when Rinpoche first came to Bhutan, he landed at Dzongdrakha. The temples are on the cliff, so you have to hike through the forest to reach the Dzongdrakha Gompa. From the Bondey town, walk for about 30 minutes to Dzongdrakha, a group of the temple overlooking the Paro valley. You will be mesmerized by the breath-taking view of the valley its surrounding provides.

placesToVisit.name: Chumphu Ney
placesToVisit.description: Chumphu Ney is situated about 3100m on a steep mountain slope. It is one of the most sacred pilgrimage places in the country. There are many unusual shaped caves and rocks formation associated with Guru Rinpoche, and each has its significance. The main relic in the temple is a statue of Dorji Phagmo (Vajravarahi), a form of Varja Yogini. From the road, it is about 4 hours hike through dense conifer, oak and bamboo forests.

Druk Choeding Lhakhang is also known as Tshongdoe temple or Tshongdoe Naktsang. It was built by Lama Ngawang Chogyel in 1525. In 1616 Druk Choeding Lhakhang was visited by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel, and it became his temporary residence. The main relic of this temple is of a seated statue of future Buddha known as Jampa.
placesToVisit.name: Druk Choeding Lhakhang

placesToVisit.description: It situated on the hilltop at an altitude of 6000 feet en route to Haa district which is approximately 37 km from Thimphu and 7km from the confluence. In 1531 the fort was built by Ngawang Chogyal, the brother of Drukpa Kuenley (Divine madman). The Dzong addressed with different names like Dogar, Dobdrek Dzong, Dokar and Dobji. It considered being the first model Dzong in the country. Today, the Dzong is home for religious relics like the statue of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel, Jetsun Milarepa Ngawang Chogyal, and Dunsay Dewa Zangpo and the gonkhang houses the Goem-Chamdal sum (Mahakali, Mahakala and the Raven Crown).
placesToVisit.name: Dobji Dzong
Bumdra Goemba
placesToVisit.description: Bumdra Goemba is the temple of one lakh Dakinis (celestial female beings) situated in Paro above Tiger Nest Monastery and Sangchokor Monastery. To practice meditation, many monks and Buddhist religious people visit the peaceful monastery. In the morning, the views are breath-taking with a beautiful sunrise, and many birds greet the place. As you trek through the forest, the first landmark will be Chhoe Tse Lhakhang, and the trek further gets into a forestry ridge which is Bhutan's untouched nature and its beauty. Finally, a breath-taking view of Paro, and Do chhu valley can see, and this is known as Bumdra.

It is always an opportunity to experience a typical village life in Bhutan. The traditional Bhutanese houses are very colourful, decorative and follow the same architectural pattern. Most traditional houses built with stones and mud without any nails. The ground floor used as a shelter for cattle during the olden day, but now it is used as a store purpose. It was a move to improve a household's hygiene and sanitation. Tourist can also eat with the host family and offers a good glimpse into the lifestyles of a farmer.
placesToVisit.name: Bhutanese Farmhouse
Restaurant in Paro
placesToVisit.description:
There are plenty of restaurants in Paro city, and almost all hotels have running restaurants. The restaurant in Paro serves cuisine like Indian, Chinese, Nepali, Bhutanese, South Indian, Continental etc. Most restaurants in Bhutan serve both vegetarian and non-vegetarian food. You can easily choose a restaurant to start your day with a delicious breakfast and elegant dinner after being tired of sightseeing.
In Paro, eating options are varied too as among budget restaurants, mid-range restaurants and upscale restaurants. Continental food is available in most restaurants and hotels in the main town. Indian dishes are also available in most restaurants and hotels. The best restaurants in Paro are Bhukari at Uma, The organic restaurant, Dagmar restaurant,  Yue-ling restaurant, lotus Bistro, Tou Zaiga restaurant, Mountain café, Taktshang cafeteria, Champaca coffee, Sonam trophel restaurant and city hotel

placesToVisit.name: Try Bhutanese Attire
placesToVisit.description: Bhutan is widely known for its deep-rooted tradition and cultural. In Bhutan, the traditional attire for women referred to as Kira and for men known as Gho, and it introduces in the 17th century to display their unique identity. To promote and preserve Bhutanese heritage, Bhutanese citizens must wear the traditional outfit. You can also try Bhutanese attire and take the photographs for memories.

usps: Home to Bhutan's only international airport
UNESCO tentative sites

name: Thimphu
description: Bhutan's capital city blends traditional culture with modern development in a unique Himalayan setting.

placesToVisit.name: Buddha Dordenma Statue
placesToVisit.description: Buddha Dordenma is a gigantic Shakyamuni Buddha statue in the mountains of Bhutan celebrating the 60th anniversary of fourth king Jigme Singye Wangchuck. The statue houses over one hundred thousand smaller Buddha statues, each of which, like the Buddha Dordenma itself, are made of bronze and gilded in gold. The Buddha Dordenma is located atop a hill in Kuenselphodrang Nature Park and overlooks the Southern entrance to Thimphu Valley. The statue fulfills an ancient prophecy found in the ancient terma of Guru Padmasambhava that was said to bestow blessings, peace and happiness on the entire world.

placesToVisit.name: Tashichho Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Tashichho Dzong is a Buddhist monastery and fortress on the northern edge of the city of Thimphu in Bhutan, on the western bank of the Wang Chu. It has traditionally been the seat of the Druk Desi (or 'Dharma Raja'), the head of Bhutan's civil government, an office which has been combined with the kingship since the creation of the monarchy in 1907, and summer capital of the country. It houses the throne room and offices of the king, the secretariat and the ministries of home affairs and finance. Other government departments are housed in buildings nearby.

placesToVisit.name: National Memorial Chorten
placesToVisit.description: The National Memorial Chorten was built in 1974 to honor the third Druk Gyalpo, Jigme Dorji Wangchuck (1928–1972), who is considered to be the father of modern Bhutan. It is a prominent landmark in the city with its golden spires and bells. The chorten is a large white structure crowned with a golden spire. Unlike other chortens, this monument does not enshrine human remains. Only a photograph of the late king is placed inside the monument. The chorten is designed in Tibetan style with a pyramidal pillar crowned by a crescent moon and sun.

placesToVisit.name: Weekend Market (Centenary Farmers Market)
placesToVisit.description: The Weekend Market in Thimphu is the most authentic way to see Thimphu's local life. It is held every Friday, Saturday and Sunday along the bank of the Wang Chhu (Thimphu river). Most of the vegetables sold here are organically grown and range from chilies, cheese, grains and other fresh vegetables. You will also find traditional handicrafts, textiles and souvenirs. The market provides an excellent opportunity to mingle with locals and experience Bhutanese culture firsthand.

placesToVisit.name: Motithang Takin Preserve
placesToVisit.description: The Motithang Takin Preserve is a wildlife reserve area for Takin, Bhutan's national animal. Originally a mini-zoo, it was converted into a preserve when it was discovered that the animals refrained from inhabiting the surrounding forest even when set free. The Takin is a rare animal, found only in Bhutan, parts of Myanmar and two provinces of China. According to Bhutanese mythology, the animal was created by the great Yogi, Drukpa Kunley, and it became a symbol of Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Changangkha Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Changangkha Lhakhang is a fortress-like temple and monastery, located on a ridge above central Thimphu. The temple was established in the 12th century by Lama Phajo Drugom Shigpo, who came from Ralung in Tibet. For the people of Thimphu, Changangkha has been a spiritual landmark and a place where parents traditionally come to get auspicious names for their newborn children from the protector deity.

placesToVisit.name: Simply Bhutan Museum
placesToVisit.description: Simply Bhutan is a living museum and photo studio that offers visitors an immersive experience of traditional Bhutanese life. Visitors can dress up in traditional Bhutanese attire, learn about rural life, try traditional archery, and enjoy cultural performances. The museum showcases traditional Bhutanese architecture, lifestyle, and customs in an interactive way.

placesToVisit.name: National Institute for Zorig Chusum
placesToVisit.description: The National Institute for Zorig Chusum (commonly known as the Painting School) provides training in Bhutan's 13 traditional arts and crafts. Students aged 13-18 undergo a six-year training program in various traditional arts including painting, woodcarving, embroidery, and sculpture. Visitors can observe students at work and purchase their creations. The institute plays a crucial role in preserving Bhutan's traditional arts and crafts.

placesToVisit.name: Folk Heritage Museum
placesToVisit.description: The Folk Heritage Museum is dedicated to connecting people to the Bhutanese rural past through exhibits, demonstrations, educational programs and documentation of rural life. The museum is housed in a replica of a traditional 19th century farmhouse and provides visitors with fascinating insights into the Bhutanese material culture and way of life. The museum also has a traditional kitchen garden growing heritage varieties of crops.

usps: Political and economic center of Bhutan

name: Punakha
description: Punakha served as Bhutan's capital until 1955 and remains the winter residence of the central monk body.

placesToVisit.name: Punakha Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Punakha Dzong, also known as Pungtang Dewa chhenbi Phodrang (meaning 'the palace of great happiness or bliss'), is the administrative centre of Punakha District in Punakha, Bhutan. Constructed by Ngawang Namgyal, 1st Zhabdrung Rinpoche, in 1637–38, it is the second oldest and second largest dzong in Bhutan and one of its most majestic structures. The dzong houses the sacred relics of the southern Drukpa Lineage of the Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, including the Rangjung Kasarpani and the sacred remains of Ngawang Namgyal and the tertön Pema Lingpa.

placesToVisit.name: Chimi Lhakhang (Fertility and Name Giving Temple)
placesToVisit.description: Chimi Lhakhang, also known as Chime Lhakhang or Fertility Temple, is a Buddhist monastery in Punakha District, Bhutan. Located on a hillock in the centre of the valley, the temple is dedicated to Drukpa Kunley, who in the late 15th century used humor, songs and outrageous behavior to dramatize his teachings and due to this also known as 'Divine Madman'. Childless women from around the world come here seeking blessings to conceive.

placesToVisit.name: Punakha Suspension Bridge
placesToVisit.description: The Punakha Suspension Bridge is one of the longest suspension bridges in Bhutan, stretching over 160 meters across the Po Chhu (Male River). The bridge connects Punakha Dzong with the villages on the other side of the river. Walking across this bridge offers spectacular views of the Punakha Valley and the dzong. The bridge is decorated with colorful prayer flags and provides an excellent photo opportunity.

placesToVisit.name: Khamsum Yulley Namgyal Chorten
placesToVisit.description: Khamsum Yulley Namgyal Chorten is a chorten in Punakha District, Bhutan. The chorten was built over 8.5 years and was consecrated in 1999. It was built for the well-being of the Kingdom of Bhutan, for peace and stability in this changing world, and to ward off negative forces and promote peace, stability and harmony in the changing world. The chorten is a 30-minute hike through rice fields and offers panoramic views of the Punakha Valley.

placesToVisit.name: Sangchhen Dorji Lhuendrup Nunnery
placesToVisit.description: Sangchhen Dorji Lhuendrup Lhakhang is a nunnery located on a ridge overlooking Punakha and Wangdue valleys. The nunnery houses a 14-foot bronze statue of Avalokiteshvara (Chenrezig) with 1000 eyes and 1000 hands. The temple also contains beautiful wall paintings and offers stunning views of the surrounding valleys. It's one of the few nunneries in Bhutan where visitors can interact with the nuns and learn about their daily life.

placesToVisit.name: Nalanda Buddhist Institute
placesToVisit.description: Nalanda Buddhist Institute is a center for higher Buddhist studies located in Punakha. The institute was established to provide advanced Buddhist education and is named after the famous Nalanda University in India. Visitors can learn about Buddhist philosophy, meditation practices, and the monastic way of life. The institute also has a beautiful library with ancient Buddhist texts and manuscripts.

placesToVisit.name: Wangchhu and Phochu Rivers Confluence
placesToVisit.description: The confluence of Wangchhu (Mother River) and Phochu (Father River) is where Punakha Dzong is strategically located. This meeting point of two rivers is considered highly auspicious in Bhutanese culture. The area offers beautiful views and is perfect for photography. During winter, the rivers are crystal clear, while in summer they carry glacial sediments giving them different colors.

placesToVisit.name: Limbukha Village
placesToVisit.description: Limbukha is a traditional Bhutanese village located in the Punakha valley. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural Bhutanese life, with traditional farmhouses, terraced fields, and friendly locals. Visitors can participate in farming activities, learn about traditional crafts, and enjoy home-cooked Bhutanese meals. The village also offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains and valleys.

placesToVisit.name: Ritsha Village
placesToVisit.description: Ritsha is a small village in Punakha known for its traditional architecture and peaceful environment. The village is surrounded by rice fields and offers stunning views of the Punakha valley. It's an excellent place for nature walks and experiencing rural Bhutanese culture. The village is also known for its traditional weaving and visitors can observe local artisans at work.

placesToVisit.name: Talo Village and Monastery
placesToVisit.description: Talo is a beautiful village located on a hilltop overlooking the Punakha valley. The village is known for its traditional houses and the Talo Monastery. The monastery is significant as it's where the Queen Mother of Bhutan spent her childhood. The village offers panoramic views of the valley and is an excellent place for hiking and photography. The area is also known for its apple orchards and traditional farming practices.

usps: Most beautiful dzong in Bhutan

name: Wangdue Phodrang
description: This diverse district features everything from subtropical valleys to alpine highlands and is famous for its wildlife.

placesToVisit.name: Gangtey Monastery (Gangtey Goenpa)
placesToVisit.description: Gangtey Monastery is an important monastery of Nyingmapa school of Buddhism, the main seat of the Pema Lingpa tradition. Located in the Phobjikha Valley, it was built in the 17th century. The monastery is perched on a small hill that rises from the valley floor and commands a spectacular view of the valley. The monastery has a meditation center and is home to over 100 monks. The annual Gangtey Tshechu festival is held here every year.

placesToVisit.name: Phobjikha Valley
placesToVisit.description: Phobjikha Valley is a glacial valley on the western slopes of the Black Mountains. It is one of the few glacial valleys in Bhutan and is the winter home of the rare black-necked cranes that migrate from Tibet. The valley is also famous for its scenic beauty with wide open grasslands and scattered farmhouses. The valley offers excellent opportunities for nature walks and bird watching.

placesToVisit.name: Black-necked Crane Information Centre
placesToVisit.description: The Black-necked Crane Information Centre was established by the Royal Society for Protection of Nature (RSPN) to educate visitors about these magnificent birds and conservation efforts. The center provides information about the cranes' migration patterns, breeding habits, and the threats they face. Visitors can use telescopes to observe the cranes in their natural habitat and learn about ongoing conservation programs.

placesToVisit.name: Gangtey Nature Trail
placesToVisit.description: The Gangtey Nature Trail is a beautiful walking trail that starts from the Gangtey Monastery and winds through the Phobjikha Valley. The trail takes about 1.5 hours to complete and offers stunning views of the valley, traditional farmhouses, and opportunities to spot black-necked cranes during winter months. The trail is well-marked and suitable for all fitness levels.

placesToVisit.name: Wangdue Phodrang Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Wangdue Phodrang Dzong was built in 1638 and is perched on a spur at the confluence of two rivers. The dzong was unfortunately damaged by fire in 2012 but has been reconstructed maintaining its original architecture. The dzong serves as the administrative center of the district and houses important religious artifacts. The location offers spectacular views of the surrounding valleys.

placesToVisit.name: Kumbu Village
placesToVisit.description: Kumbu is a traditional village in the Phobjikha Valley known for its potato farming and traditional architecture. The village offers visitors a chance to experience rural Bhutanese life and participate in farming activities. The village is also a good spot for observing black-necked cranes and offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains.

placesToVisit.name: Khewang Village
placesToVisit.description: Khewang is another traditional village in the Phobjikha Valley, known for its friendly locals and traditional way of life. The village is surrounded by beautiful landscapes and offers excellent opportunities for cultural immersion. Visitors can stay with local families, participate in daily activities, and learn about traditional Bhutanese customs.

placesToVisit.name: Longtey Village
placesToVisit.description: Longtey is a small village located at the edge of the Phobjikha Valley. The village is known for its traditional houses and beautiful mountain views. It's an excellent place for hiking and offers a peaceful environment away from the crowds. The village is also known for its traditional crafts and visitors can observe local artisans at work.

placesToVisit.name: Sha Radap
placesToVisit.description: Sha Radap is a scenic viewpoint that offers panoramic views of the Phobjikha Valley and surrounding mountains. The viewpoint is accessible by a short hike and is particularly beautiful during sunrise and sunset. It's an excellent spot for photography and meditation, offering a peaceful environment surrounded by nature.

placesToVisit.name: Tabiting Village
placesToVisit.description: Tabiting is a traditional village located on the slopes above the Phobjikha Valley. The village offers stunning views of the valley below and is known for its traditional architecture and farming practices. Visitors can explore the village, interact with locals, and learn about traditional Bhutanese culture. The village is also a good starting point for hiking trails in the area.

usps: Important conservation area for endangered cranes

name: Bumthang
description: Bumthang is considered Bhutan's most sacred region, with numerous ancient temples and monasteries dotting its four valleys.

placesToVisit.name: Jakar Dzong (Castle of the White Bird)
placesToVisit.description: Jakar Dzong, also known as the 'Castle of the White Bird', is a Buddhist monastery and fortress located in the Bumthang valley. Built in 1549, it is the largest dzong in Bhutan in terms of its circumference. The dzong serves as the administrative center of Bumthang district and houses the district monastic body during winter months. The dzong offers spectacular views of the Choekhor valley and surrounding mountains.

placesToVisit.name: Jambay Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Jambay Lhakhang is one of the oldest temples in Bhutan, built in the 7th century by the Tibetan King Songtsen Gampo. The temple is one of 108 temples built in a single day to subdue a demoness. The temple houses a statue of Maitreya (future Buddha) and is famous for its annual Jambay Lhakhang Drup festival, which features sacred mask dances and the famous fire ceremony performed at midnight.

placesToVisit.name: Kurjey Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Kurjey Lhakhang is one of the most sacred places in Bhutan, consisting of three temples built around the cave where Guru Rinpoche meditated in the 8th century. The name 'Kurjey' means 'body imprint' referring to the body imprint of Guru Rinpoche left on the rock inside the cave. The complex is surrounded by a wall with 108 chortens and is considered one of the most important pilgrimage sites in Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Tamshing Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Tamshing Lhakhang was founded in 1501 by Pema Lingpa, Bhutan's greatest treasure discoverer (tertön). The temple houses some of the oldest and most beautiful religious paintings in Bhutan, depicting the life of Guru Rinpoche. The temple is also famous for its annual Tamshing Phala Choepa festival, which features sacred mask dances based on visions of Pema Lingpa.

placesToVisit.name: Mebar Tsho (Burning Lake)
placesToVisit.description: Mebar Tsho, known as the Burning Lake, is a sacred site where Pema Lingpa discovered several of Guru Rinpoche's hidden treasures (terma) in the 15th century. The lake is considered one of the most sacred sites in Bhutan. According to legend, Pema Lingpa jumped into the lake with a burning lamp and emerged with the lamp still burning and treasures in his hands. The site is marked by prayer flags and offers a peaceful environment for meditation.

placesToVisit.name: Swiss Farm
placesToVisit.description: Swiss Farm is a cheese and apple farm established by Swiss development aid in the 1960s. The farm produces some of the finest cheese in Bhutan and offers visitors a chance to learn about cheese-making processes. The farm also has apple orchards and offers apple products. Visitors can tour the facilities, taste different varieties of cheese, and purchase farm products.

placesToVisit.name: Bumthang Brewery
placesToVisit.description: Bumthang Brewery is famous for producing Red Panda Beer, one of Bhutan's most popular beers. The brewery uses pure Himalayan spring water and offers tours where visitors can learn about the beer-making process. The brewery also has a tasting room where visitors can sample different varieties of beer and purchase brewery products.

placesToVisit.name: Ura Valley
placesToVisit.description: Ura Valley is one of the four valleys of Bumthang and is known for its traditional village and beautiful landscapes. The valley is home to Ura village, which maintains traditional Bhutanese architecture and way of life. The valley offers excellent opportunities for hiking, cultural immersion, and experiencing rural Bhutanese life. The annual Ura Yakchoe festival is held here every year.

placesToVisit.name: Tang Valley
placesToVisit.description: Tang Valley is the most remote of Bumthang's four valleys and is known for its pristine natural beauty and traditional way of life. The valley is home to several important temples and offers excellent trekking opportunities. The valley is also famous for its yak herding communities and traditional architecture. Visitors can experience authentic rural Bhutanese culture and enjoy spectacular mountain views.

placesToVisit.name: Choekhor Valley
placesToVisit.description: Choekhor Valley is the main valley of Bumthang and houses most of the important temples and dzongs. The valley is known for its fertile farmlands, traditional villages, and numerous sacred sites. It's the cultural and administrative center of Bumthang and offers visitors the best introduction to the region's rich spiritual heritage.

usps: Highest concentration of sacred sites in Bhutan

name: Trongsa
description: Strategically located in central Bhutan, Trongsa has historically controlled east-west travel and was the seat of Bhutan's monarchy.

placesToVisit.name: Trongsa Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Trongsa Dzong is the largest dzong fortress in Bhutan, built in 1648. It controls the ancient trade route between east and west Bhutan and has been the seat of power over central and eastern Bhutan. The dzong is built on multiple levels on a steep ridge and offers spectacular views of the Mangde river valley. It houses the district administration and the monastic body of Trongsa.

placesToVisit.name: Ta Dzong (Tower of Trongsa Museum)
placesToVisit.description: The Tower of Trongsa Museum is housed in the Ta Dzong (watchtower) built in 1652. The museum showcases the history of the Wangchuck dynasty and contains artifacts, weapons, and religious objects. The museum provides insights into Bhutan's monarchy and the role of Trongsa in Bhutanese history. The tower offers panoramic views of the Trongsa Dzong and surrounding valleys.

placesToVisit.name: Chendebji Chorten
placesToVisit.description: Chendebji Chorten is a large Nepalese-style stupa built in the 18th century by Lama Shida from Tibet. The chorten was built to cover the remains of an evil spirit and is modeled after Swayambhunath stupa in Kathmandu. The chorten is surrounded by prayer wheels and offers a peaceful environment for meditation. It's located on the way to Trongsa from the west.

placesToVisit.name: Kuenga Rabten Palace
placesToVisit.description: Kuenga Rabten is the winter palace of the second king of Bhutan, built in 1900. The palace showcases traditional Bhutanese architecture and houses a small temple. The palace is surrounded by beautiful gardens and offers insights into royal life in early 20th century Bhutan. Visitors can explore the palace rooms and learn about the history of the Bhutanese monarchy.

placesToVisit.name: Trongsa Market
placesToVisit.description: Trongsa Market is a traditional Bhutanese market where locals sell fresh produce, handicrafts, and traditional items. The market offers visitors a chance to experience local life and purchase authentic Bhutanese products. The market is particularly lively during weekends and offers a variety of local foods, textiles, and souvenirs.

placesToVisit.name: Mangde Chhu River
placesToVisit.description: The Mangde Chhu River flows through the Trongsa valley and offers beautiful scenery and opportunities for nature walks. The river is surrounded by lush forests and provides habitat for various bird species. Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank and experience the natural beauty of central Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Pele La Pass
placesToVisit.description: Pele La Pass at 3,300 meters is the traditional boundary between western and central Bhutan. The pass is marked by a large collection of prayer flags and offers stunning views of the surrounding mountains. The pass is also the boundary between two different vegetation zones and offers excellent opportunities for photography and nature observation.

usps: Birthplace of Bhutan's monarchy

name: Mongar
description: Mongar serves as the cultural and administrative hub of eastern Bhutan, known for its dramatic landscapes and traditional weaving.

placesToVisit.name: Mongar Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Mongar Dzong is one of the newest dzongs in Bhutan, built in 1930s to replace the old Zhongar Dzong. The dzong is built in traditional Bhutanese architecture without using any nails or iron. It serves as the administrative center of Mongar district and houses the district monastic body. The dzong offers beautiful views of the Kuri Chhu river valley and surrounding mountains.

placesToVisit.name: Drametse Monastery
placesToVisit.description: Drametse Monastery is famous for its sacred Drametse Ngacham (drum dance) which is inscribed on UNESCO's Representative List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. The monastery was founded in the 16th century and is located on a hilltop offering panoramic views of the eastern valleys. The monastery houses important religious artifacts and is known for its annual festival featuring the famous drum dance.

placesToVisit.name: Zhongar Dzong Ruins
placesToVisit.description: Zhongar Dzong is the ruins of an old fortress that once served as the administrative center before Mongar Dzong was built. The ruins are located on a strategic hilltop and offer insights into Bhutan's medieval architecture and defense systems. The site provides excellent views of the surrounding valleys and is a good spot for photography and historical exploration.

placesToVisit.name: Yagang Village
placesToVisit.description: Yagang is a traditional village known for its weaving traditions and production of traditional textiles. The village is home to skilled weavers who create beautiful traditional Bhutanese fabrics using traditional looms. Visitors can observe the weaving process, learn about traditional techniques, and purchase authentic handwoven textiles. The village also offers beautiful mountain views and traditional architecture.

placesToVisit.name: Kori La Pass
placesToVisit.description: Kori La Pass at 2,298 meters connects Mongar with Bumthang and offers spectacular views of the eastern Himalayas. The pass is marked by colorful prayer flags and provides excellent opportunities for photography. The area around the pass is rich in rhododendron forests and offers good birdwatching opportunities. The pass is also a good spot for short hikes and nature walks.

placesToVisit.name: Mongar Market
placesToVisit.description: Mongar Market is a bustling local market where farmers and traders from surrounding villages come to sell their produce. The market offers fresh vegetables, fruits, traditional handicrafts, and textiles. It's an excellent place to experience local life and culture, interact with locals, and purchase authentic Bhutanese products. The market is particularly lively during weekends.

placesToVisit.name: Shertang Village
placesToVisit.description: Shertang is a traditional village located in a beautiful valley setting. The village is known for its traditional architecture, friendly locals, and agricultural practices. Visitors can experience rural Bhutanese life, participate in farming activities, and enjoy home-cooked traditional meals. The village offers beautiful views of terraced fields and surrounding mountains.

placesToVisit.name: Kuri Chhu River
placesToVisit.description: The Kuri Chhu River flows through Mongar and provides beautiful scenery and opportunities for nature walks. The river is surrounded by lush forests and agricultural fields. Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, observe local wildlife, and experience the natural beauty of eastern Bhutan. The river also provides opportunities for fishing and picnicking.

usps: Famous for high-quality textile production

name: Trashigang
description: Bhutan's largest and most populous eastern district, known for its vibrant culture and important trade routes.

placesToVisit.name: Trashigang Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Trashigang Dzong, built in 1659, is strategically located on a spur overlooking the Dangme Chhu and Gamri Chhu rivers. The dzong serves as the administrative center of Trashigang district and is one of the most impressive dzongs in eastern Bhutan. The dzong houses important religious artifacts and offers spectacular views of the surrounding valleys. It's also the venue for the annual Trashigang Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Merak and Sakteng Villages
placesToVisit.description: Merak and Sakteng are remote villages inhabited by the Brokpa people, a semi-nomadic community with unique culture and traditions. The villages are located in the Sakteng Wildlife Sanctuary and offer opportunities to experience a unique way of life. The Brokpa people have their own language, dress, and customs distinct from other Bhutanese communities. The area also offers excellent trekking opportunities and wildlife viewing.

placesToVisit.name: Radhi Village
placesToVisit.description: Radhi is famous for producing the finest raw silk textiles in Bhutan. The village is known for its traditional weaving techniques and produces the highly prized 'Bura' textiles worn by Bhutanese royalty. Visitors can observe the silk production process from silkworm rearing to the final weaving. The village also offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains and traditional Bhutanese architecture.

placesToVisit.name: Kanglung (Sherubtse College)
placesToVisit.description: Kanglung is home to Sherubtse College, Bhutan's first degree-granting college and now part of the Royal University of Bhutan. The college campus offers beautiful views of the eastern valleys and mountains. Visitors can explore the campus, interact with students and faculty, and learn about higher education in Bhutan. The area also offers good hiking opportunities and cultural experiences.

placesToVisit.name: Trashigang Market
placesToVisit.description: Trashigang Market is the largest market in eastern Bhutan and serves as a trading hub for the region. The market offers a wide variety of goods including fresh produce, traditional handicrafts, textiles, and imported goods from India. It's an excellent place to experience local life, interact with traders from different regions, and purchase authentic eastern Bhutanese products.

usps: Commercial hub of eastern Bhutan

name: Samdrup Jongkhar
description: Bhutan's southeastern frontier town bordering India, known for its tropical climate and commercial importance.

placesToVisit.name: Zangdo Pelri Lhakhang
placesToVisit.description: Zangdo Pelri Lhakhang is a beautiful temple representing Guru Rinpoche's celestial paradise. The temple features intricate wall paintings depicting the pure land of Guru Rinpoche and houses important religious artifacts. The temple is an important pilgrimage site for local communities and offers insights into Bhutanese Buddhist beliefs about the afterlife and spiritual realms.

placesToVisit.name: Dewathang
placesToVisit.description: Dewathang is a small town that serves as an important transit point between Bhutan and India. The town has a mixed population and offers insights into the multicultural nature of southern Bhutan. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with diverse communities, and experience the unique blend of Bhutanese and Indian cultures that characterizes the border regions.

placesToVisit.name: Samdrup Jongkhar Market
placesToVisit.description: Samdrup Jongkhar Market is a bustling border market where goods from India and Bhutan are traded. The market offers a wide variety of products including fresh produce, textiles, electronics, and traditional handicrafts. It's an excellent place to experience the commercial life of border towns and observe the cultural exchange between Bhutan and India.

placesToVisit.name: Jomotsangkha Wildlife Sanctuary
placesToVisit.description: Jomotsangkha Wildlife Sanctuary is located in the subtropical region and is home to diverse wildlife including elephants, tigers, and various bird species. The sanctuary offers opportunities for wildlife viewing, birdwatching, and nature walks. The area is part of the transboundary conservation complex with India's Manas National Park and provides important habitat for endangered species.

placesToVisit.name: Manas River
placesToVisit.description: The Manas River forms part of the border between Bhutan and India and is an important waterway in the region. The river supports diverse aquatic life and provides water for irrigation and hydroelectric power generation. Visitors can enjoy scenic walks along the riverbank, observe local wildlife, and experience the natural beauty of southern Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Pemathang
placesToVisit.description: Pemathang is a small settlement known for its agricultural activities and traditional way of life. The area is surrounded by lush forests and agricultural fields. Visitors can experience rural life in southern Bhutan, participate in farming activities, and enjoy the peaceful environment away from urban areas.

placesToVisit.name: Martshala
placesToVisit.description: Martshala is a border checkpoint and small town that serves as an entry point to Bhutan from India. The town offers insights into border life and the movement of people and goods between the two countries. Visitors can observe the customs and immigration procedures and experience the unique atmosphere of border towns.

usps: Main trading hub with India

name: Pemagatshel
description: A small eastern district known for its pristine forests and traditional Buddhist culture.

placesToVisit.name: Pemagatshel Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Pemagatshel Dzong serves as the administrative and religious center of the district. Built in traditional Bhutanese architecture, the dzong houses the district administration and monastic body. The dzong is located on a hilltop and offers beautiful views of the surrounding valleys and mountains. It's also the venue for the annual Pemagatshel Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Yurung Village
placesToVisit.description: Yurung is a traditional village known for its pristine natural environment and traditional way of life. The village is surrounded by dense forests and offers excellent opportunities for nature walks and birdwatching. Visitors can experience authentic rural Bhutanese culture, stay with local families, and participate in traditional farming activities.

placesToVisit.name: Nganglam Town
placesToVisit.description: Nganglam is a small town that serves as an important transit point in eastern Bhutan. The town has a mixed population and offers insights into the multicultural nature of the region. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with diverse communities, and experience the unique blend of cultures that characterizes this part of Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Khaling Wildlife Sanctuary
placesToVisit.description: Khaling Wildlife Sanctuary is a protected area that preserves the biodiversity of eastern Bhutan. The sanctuary is home to various wildlife species including clouded leopards, red pandas, and numerous bird species. Visitors can enjoy nature walks, wildlife viewing, and birdwatching in this pristine natural environment.

placesToVisit.name: Dungmin Village
placesToVisit.description: Dungmin is a remote village known for its traditional architecture and peaceful environment. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural life and traditional Bhutanese culture. The area is surrounded by beautiful landscapes and offers excellent opportunities for hiking and photography.

placesToVisit.name: Khar Village
placesToVisit.description: Khar is a traditional village located in a beautiful valley setting. The village is known for its traditional houses, terraced fields, and friendly locals. Visitors can explore the village, learn about traditional farming practices, and enjoy the peaceful rural environment.

placesToVisit.name: Chongshing Village
placesToVisit.description: Chongshing is a small village known for its traditional weaving and handicrafts. The village produces beautiful traditional textiles and offers visitors a chance to observe the weaving process and purchase authentic handmade products. The village also offers beautiful mountain views and traditional architecture.

usps: Least visited district with pristine nature

name: Haa
description: Bhutan's westernmost valley bordering Tibet, known for its sacred sites and traditional way of life.

placesToVisit.name: Lhakhang Karpo (White Temple)
placesToVisit.description: Lhakhang Karpo, the White Temple, is one of the most sacred temples in Haa valley. According to legend, the temple was built where a white pigeon, a manifestation of a deity, landed. The temple houses important religious artifacts and is considered a powerful place for prayers and meditation. The temple offers beautiful views of the Haa valley and surrounding mountains.

placesToVisit.name: Lhakhang Nagpo (Black Temple)
placesToVisit.description: Lhakhang Nagpo, the Black Temple, is located near Lhakhang Karpo and is equally sacred. Legend says it was built where a black pigeon landed. The temple is dedicated to protective deities and is known for its powerful spiritual energy. Local people believe that prayers offered here are particularly effective for protection and overcoming obstacles.

placesToVisit.name: Haa Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Haa Dzong, also known as Wangchulo Dzong, was built in 1915 and serves as the administrative center of Haa district. The dzong is built in traditional Bhutanese architecture and houses the district administration. The dzong is located in a strategic position overlooking the Haa valley and offers beautiful views of the surrounding landscape.

placesToVisit.name: Haa Summer Festival Ground
placesToVisit.description: The Haa Summer Festival is held annually in July to promote the unique culture and traditions of the Haa valley. The festival features traditional sports, cultural performances, local cuisine, and handicraft exhibitions. The festival ground offers beautiful views of the valley and provides an excellent opportunity to experience local culture and traditions.

placesToVisit.name: Juneydrak Hermitage
placesToVisit.description: Juneydrak Hermitage is a sacred meditation retreat located on a cliff above the Haa valley. The hermitage was used by great Buddhist masters for meditation and spiritual practice. The site offers spectacular views of the valley and surrounding mountains. It's accessible by a challenging hike and provides a peaceful environment for meditation and reflection.

placesToVisit.name: Katsho Village
placesToVisit.description: Katsho is a traditional village in the Haa valley known for its beautiful traditional houses and agricultural practices. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural Bhutanese life and traditional farming methods. The village is surrounded by beautiful landscapes and offers excellent opportunities for cultural immersion and photography.

placesToVisit.name: Uesu Village
placesToVisit.description: Uesu is a traditional village known for its potato farming and beautiful mountain setting. The village offers visitors a chance to experience rural life in the Haa valley and participate in traditional farming activities. The village is surrounded by terraced fields and offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains.

usps: Most remote western valley with Tibetan influence

name: Samtse
description: Bhutan's southwestern border district with a diverse ethnic population and subtropical climate.

placesToVisit.name: Samtse Town
placesToVisit.description: Samtse is the main town of the district and serves as an important administrative and commercial center. The town has a diverse population representing different ethnic communities of Bhutan. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with diverse communities, and experience the multicultural nature of southern Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Torsa River
placesToVisit.description: The Torsa River flows through Samtse district and provides important water resources for the region. The river supports diverse aquatic life and provides opportunities for fishing and boating. Visitors can enjoy scenic walks along the riverbank and observe local wildlife in the riparian forests.

placesToVisit.name: Phuntsholing Border
placesToVisit.description: Phuntsholing is Bhutan's main border town with India and serves as the primary entry point for visitors arriving by land. The town offers a unique blend of Bhutanese and Indian cultures and is an important commercial center. Visitors can experience the bustling border atmosphere and observe the cultural exchange between the two countries.

placesToVisit.name: Gomtu Village
placesToVisit.description: Gomtu is a traditional village in Samtse known for its agricultural activities and traditional way of life. The village is surrounded by lush forests and agricultural fields. Visitors can experience rural life in southern Bhutan, participate in farming activities, and enjoy the peaceful environment.

placesToVisit.name: Sipsu Village
placesToVisit.description: Sipsu is a small village known for its traditional architecture and cultural practices. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural Bhutanese culture and traditional way of life. The area is surrounded by beautiful natural landscapes and offers opportunities for nature walks and cultural immersion.

usps: Most ethnically diverse district in Bhutan

name: Chhukha
description: Bhutan's industrial and hydropower hub located along the main highway to India.

placesToVisit.name: Tala Hydroelectric Project
placesToVisit.description: Tala Hydroelectric Project is one of Bhutan's largest hydropower plants with a capacity of 1020 MW. The project is a joint venture between Bhutan and India and represents Bhutan's commitment to clean energy. Visitors can take guided tours of the facility to learn about hydropower generation and its importance to Bhutan's economy. The project site offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains and valleys.

placesToVisit.name: Gedu Town
placesToVisit.description: Gedu is an important town in Chhukha district that serves as a commercial and administrative center. The town is located along the main highway connecting Bhutan with India and is an important transit point. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with locals, and experience the commercial life of this important highway town.

placesToVisit.name: Wangchhu River
placesToVisit.description: The Wangchhu River flows through Chhukha district and is the source of power for several hydroelectric projects. The river provides beautiful scenery and opportunities for nature walks and photography. The river valley is also important for agriculture and supports diverse wildlife.

placesToVisit.name: Chapcha Town
placesToVisit.description: Chapcha is a small town that serves as an administrative center in Chhukha district. The town offers insights into local governance and administration in Bhutan. Visitors can explore the town, interact with local officials, and learn about district-level administration in Bhutan.

usps: Produces most of Bhutan's electricity

name: Dagana
description: A central district known for its bamboo forests and traditional crafts.

placesToVisit.name: Daga Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Daga Dzong serves as the administrative and religious center of Dagana district. The dzong is built in traditional Bhutanese architecture and houses the district administration and monastic body. The dzong is located on a hilltop and offers beautiful views of the surrounding valleys and bamboo forests. It's also the venue for the annual Daga Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Dagapela Town
placesToVisit.description: Dagapela is the main town of Dagana district and serves as the commercial and administrative center. The town is known for its bamboo products and traditional crafts. Visitors can explore the local market, purchase bamboo handicrafts, and learn about the traditional uses of bamboo in Bhutanese culture.

placesToVisit.name: Bamboo Craft Center
placesToVisit.description: The Bamboo Craft Center showcases the traditional art of bamboo weaving and crafting. Visitors can observe skilled artisans creating various bamboo products including baskets, containers, and decorative items. The center also offers workshops where visitors can learn basic bamboo crafting techniques and create their own souvenirs.

placesToVisit.name: Kana Village
placesToVisit.description: Kana is a traditional village known for its bamboo forests and traditional way of life. The village is surrounded by extensive bamboo groves and offers visitors a chance to experience rural Bhutanese culture. Visitors can participate in bamboo harvesting, learn about traditional uses of bamboo, and enjoy the peaceful village atmosphere.

placesToVisit.name: Bamboo Forest Trail
placesToVisit.description: The Bamboo Forest Trail is a beautiful walking trail that winds through extensive bamboo groves in Dagana. The trail offers visitors a unique opportunity to experience one of Bhutan's most important natural resources up close. The trail is suitable for all fitness levels and provides excellent opportunities for photography and nature observation.

placesToVisit.name: Daga River
placesToVisit.description: The Daga River flows through the district and provides important water resources for local communities. The river is surrounded by lush forests and bamboo groves. Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, observe local wildlife, and experience the natural beauty of central Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Lhamoizingkha Town
placesToVisit.description: Lhamoizingkha is an important town in Dagana district that serves as a commercial center. The town is located along the main highway and is known for its markets and trading activities. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with traders, and experience the commercial life of this important highway town.

usps: Largest bamboo forests in Bhutan

name: Tsirang
description: A subtropical district known for its biodiversity and traditional medicine practices.

placesToVisit.name: Damphu Town
placesToVisit.description: Damphu is the administrative center of Tsirang district and is known for its subtropical climate and diverse flora. The town serves as a hub for traditional medicine practitioners and medicinal plant collectors. Visitors can explore the local market, which offers various medicinal plants and traditional remedies, and learn about the importance of traditional medicine in Bhutanese culture.

placesToVisit.name: Traditional Medicine Institute
placesToVisit.description: The Traditional Medicine Institute in Tsirang is dedicated to preserving and promoting Bhutan's traditional healing practices. The institute conducts research on medicinal plants, trains traditional healers, and provides healthcare services using traditional methods. Visitors can learn about traditional diagnostic techniques, medicinal plant preparation, and the integration of traditional and modern medicine in Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Medicinal Plant Garden
placesToVisit.description: The Medicinal Plant Garden showcases over 200 species of medicinal plants found in Bhutan. The garden serves as a living laboratory for research and education about traditional medicine. Visitors can take guided tours to learn about different medicinal plants, their uses, and preparation methods. The garden also offers workshops on traditional medicine and plant identification.

placesToVisit.name: Tsirang Toed
placesToVisit.description: Tsirang Toed is a sacred site associated with traditional healing practices. The site is believed to have special healing powers and is visited by people seeking traditional treatments. The area is surrounded by medicinal plants and offers a peaceful environment for meditation and healing. Local traditional healers often conduct ceremonies and treatments at this sacred site.

placesToVisit.name: Subtropical Forest Reserve
placesToVisit.description: The Subtropical Forest Reserve in Tsirang protects important biodiversity and serves as a source of medicinal plants. The forest is home to various wildlife species and offers excellent opportunities for birdwatching and nature walks. Visitors can explore the forest trails, observe diverse flora and fauna, and learn about forest conservation efforts in Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Barshong Village
placesToVisit.description: Barshong is a traditional village known for its medicinal plant collectors and traditional healers. The village offers visitors a chance to experience rural life and learn about traditional medicine practices from local experts. Visitors can participate in medicinal plant collection, observe traditional healing ceremonies, and learn about the role of traditional medicine in rural communities.

placesToVisit.name: Mendrelgang Town
placesToVisit.description: Mendrelgang is an important town in Tsirang that serves as a commercial center for the region. The town is known for its markets selling medicinal plants, traditional remedies, and local produce. Visitors can explore the bustling market, interact with local traders, and purchase authentic traditional medicines and herbal products.

placesToVisit.name: Patshaling Village
placesToVisit.description: Patshaling is a village known for its traditional architecture and agricultural practices. The village is surrounded by medicinal plant gardens and offers visitors a chance to experience rural Bhutanese culture. Visitors can explore traditional houses, participate in farming activities, and learn about the integration of medicinal plant cultivation with traditional agriculture.

usps: Center for traditional Bhutanese medicine

name: Sarpang
description: Bhutan's southernmost district with tropical climate and diverse ethnic communities.

placesToVisit.name: Royal Manas National Park
placesToVisit.description: Royal Manas National Park is Bhutan's oldest national park and a UNESCO World Heritage site. The park protects tropical and subtropical ecosystems and is home to diverse wildlife including tigers, elephants, rhinoceros, and over 365 bird species. Visitors can enjoy jungle safaris, wildlife viewing, birdwatching, and nature walks. The park offers excellent opportunities to experience Bhutan's tropical biodiversity.

placesToVisit.name: Gelephu Town
placesToVisit.description: Gelephu is the largest town in southern Bhutan and an important commercial center bordering India. The town has a diverse population and serves as a major trading hub. Visitors can explore the bustling markets, experience the multicultural atmosphere, and observe the commercial activities that make Gelephu an important economic center for southern Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Manas River
placesToVisit.description: The Manas River forms the southern boundary of Bhutan with India and is an important waterway in the region. The river supports diverse aquatic life and provides water for irrigation and wildlife. Visitors can enjoy boat rides, fishing, and wildlife viewing along the riverbank. The river is also important for the ecosystem of Royal Manas National Park.

placesToVisit.name: Sarpang Town
placesToVisit.description: Sarpang is the administrative center of the district and serves as an important hub for the region. The town offers insights into local governance and administration in southern Bhutan. Visitors can explore the town, interact with local officials, and learn about the challenges and opportunities of governing Bhutan's most diverse district.

placesToVisit.name: Tropical Wildlife Sanctuary
placesToVisit.description: The Tropical Wildlife Sanctuary protects important tropical ecosystems and serves as a corridor for wildlife movement between protected areas. The sanctuary is home to various endangered species and offers excellent opportunities for wildlife viewing and research. Visitors can participate in guided tours, wildlife monitoring activities, and conservation programs.

placesToVisit.name: Umling Village
placesToVisit.description: Umling is a traditional village that represents the diverse ethnic communities of southern Bhutan. The village offers visitors a chance to experience the unique culture and traditions of the region's indigenous communities. Visitors can participate in cultural activities, learn about traditional practices, and enjoy the hospitality of the local people.

placesToVisit.name: Shompangkha Town
placesToVisit.description: Shompangkha is an important town that serves as a gateway to Royal Manas National Park. The town offers accommodation and services for visitors to the national park. Visitors can use Shompangkha as a base for exploring the park, interacting with local guides, and learning about conservation efforts in the region.

placesToVisit.name: Jigme Singye Wangchuck National Park (Southern Section)
placesToVisit.description: The southern section of Jigme Singye Wangchuck National Park extends into Sarpang district and protects important montane ecosystems. The park is home to diverse wildlife and offers excellent trekking opportunities. Visitors can explore the park's trails, observe wildlife, and experience the transition from tropical to temperate ecosystems.

usps: Home to Bhutan's oldest national park

name: Zhemgang
description: Central Bhutan's most remote district, known for its pristine forests and traditional culture.

placesToVisit.name: Zhemgang Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Zhemgang Dzong serves as the administrative and religious center of this remote district. Built in traditional Bhutanese architecture, the dzong houses the district administration and monastic body. The dzong is strategically located and offers beautiful views of the surrounding valleys and forests. It's also the venue for the annual Zhemgang Tshechu festival, which showcases the unique Kheng culture.

placesToVisit.name: Kheng Villages
placesToVisit.description: The Kheng villages of Zhemgang preserve one of Bhutan's most ancient cultures. The Kheng people have their own language, traditions, and customs that are distinct from other Bhutanese communities. Visitors can experience authentic Kheng culture, observe traditional practices, participate in community activities, and learn about this unique ethnic group's way of life.

placesToVisit.name: Traditional Weaving Center
placesToVisit.description: The Traditional Weaving Center showcases the unique textile traditions of the Kheng people. The center preserves ancient weaving techniques and produces traditional Kheng textiles that are highly valued throughout Bhutan. Visitors can observe skilled weavers at work, learn about traditional dyeing techniques using natural materials, and purchase authentic Kheng textiles.

placesToVisit.name: Mangde Chhu River Valley
placesToVisit.description: The Mangde Chhu River Valley is one of Bhutan's most pristine and biodiverse areas. The valley is home to ancient forests, diverse wildlife, and traditional Kheng settlements. Visitors can enjoy nature walks, wildlife viewing, and experience the untouched natural beauty of central Bhutan. The valley also offers excellent opportunities for photography and meditation.

placesToVisit.name: Royal Manas National Park (Northern Section)
placesToVisit.description: The northern section of Royal Manas National Park extends into Zhemgang and protects important temperate and subtropical ecosystems. This area is less visited than the southern section and offers opportunities for wilderness experiences and wildlife viewing. The park is home to golden langurs, tigers, and numerous bird species.

placesToVisit.name: Tingtibi Town
placesToVisit.description: Tingtibi is an important town in Zhemgang that serves as a commercial and administrative center. The town is located along the main road connecting central and southern Bhutan. Visitors can explore the local market, interact with the diverse population, and experience the unique blend of cultures that characterizes this remote region.

placesToVisit.name: Buli Village
placesToVisit.description: Buli is a traditional Kheng village that maintains ancient customs and practices. The village offers visitors an authentic experience of Kheng culture and traditional way of life. Visitors can stay with local families, participate in traditional activities, and learn about the unique customs and beliefs of the Kheng people.

placesToVisit.name: Panbang Wildlife Sanctuary
placesToVisit.description: Panbang Wildlife Sanctuary protects important wildlife corridors and biodiversity hotspots in Zhemgang. The sanctuary is home to various endangered species and offers excellent opportunities for wildlife research and conservation activities. Visitors can participate in wildlife monitoring programs and learn about conservation efforts in this remote region.

usps: Most remote district with unique Kheng culture

name: Lhuentse
description: The ancestral home of Bhutan's royal family, known for its pristine environment and traditional culture.

placesToVisit.name: Lhuentse Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Lhuentse Dzong, built in 1654, is historically significant as the ancestral home of Bhutan's royal family. The dzong is perched on a steep ridge overlooking the Kuri Chhu river and serves as the administrative center of the district. The dzong houses important religious artifacts and offers spectacular views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. It's also the venue for the annual Lhuentse Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Khoma Village
placesToVisit.description: Khoma village is renowned for producing the finest traditional textiles in Bhutan, particularly the highly prized 'Kishuthara' fabric. The village is home to skilled weavers who create intricate patterns using traditional techniques passed down through generations. Visitors can observe the weaving process, learn about traditional dyeing methods, and purchase authentic handwoven textiles directly from the artisans.

placesToVisit.name: Kilung Village
placesToVisit.description: Kilung is a traditional village known for its well-preserved architecture and cultural practices. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural Bhutanese life and traditional customs. Visitors can stay with local families, participate in farming activities, and learn about traditional crafts and customs that have been preserved for centuries.

placesToVisit.name: Gangzur Village
placesToVisit.description: Gangzur is a remote village that maintains traditional ways of life and ancient customs. The village is known for its traditional architecture, terraced fields, and friendly locals. Visitors can experience authentic rural culture, participate in traditional activities, and enjoy the peaceful mountain environment away from modern distractions.

placesToVisit.name: Kuri Chhu River
placesToVisit.description: The Kuri Chhu River flows through Lhuentse district and provides beautiful scenery and opportunities for nature activities. The river is surrounded by pristine forests and supports diverse wildlife. Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, observe local wildlife, and experience the natural beauty of eastern Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Menbi Village
placesToVisit.description: Menbi is a traditional village known for its agricultural practices and traditional way of life. The village is surrounded by terraced fields and offers beautiful mountain views. Visitors can experience rural Bhutanese culture, participate in farming activities, and learn about traditional agricultural techniques that have been used for generations.

placesToVisit.name: Tangmachu Village
placesToVisit.description: Tangmachu is a small village located in a beautiful valley setting. The village is known for its traditional houses, friendly locals, and peaceful environment. Visitors can explore the village, interact with locals, and enjoy the serene mountain atmosphere. The village also offers good hiking opportunities and beautiful photography locations.

usps: Ancestral home of Bhutan's royal family

name: Trashiyangtse
description: Famous for its traditional crafts, particularly woodcarving and the sacred Chorten Kora.

placesToVisit.name: Chorten Kora
placesToVisit.description: Chorten Kora is one of the most important pilgrimage sites in eastern Bhutan, built in the 18th century and modeled after the Boudhanath stupa in Nepal. The large white stupa attracts thousands of pilgrims annually, especially during the Chorten Kora festival. Pilgrims circumambulate the chorten while spinning prayer wheels and chanting prayers. The site offers beautiful views of the Kulong Chhu river valley.

placesToVisit.name: Trashiyangtse Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Trashiyangtse Dzong, built in 1656, serves as the administrative and religious center of the district. The dzong is strategically located on a ridge overlooking the Kulong Chhu river and offers spectacular views of the surrounding valleys. The dzong houses important religious artifacts and serves as the venue for the annual Trashiyangtse Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Traditional Arts and Crafts Center
placesToVisit.description: The Traditional Arts and Crafts Center in Trashiyangtse is famous for producing some of Bhutan's finest woodcarvings, traditional bowls, and other handicrafts. The center trains young artisans in traditional techniques and preserves ancient craft traditions. Visitors can observe skilled craftsmen at work, learn about traditional techniques, and purchase authentic handmade products.

placesToVisit.name: Bomdeling Wildlife Sanctuary
placesToVisit.description: Bomdeling Wildlife Sanctuary is an important conservation area that protects the winter habitat of black-necked cranes and other wildlife species. The sanctuary offers excellent opportunities for birdwatching, wildlife viewing, and nature photography. Visitors can observe the rare black-necked cranes during winter months and learn about conservation efforts to protect these endangered birds.

placesToVisit.name: Gom Kora Temple
placesToVisit.description: Gom Kora Temple is a sacred site located on the banks of the Kulong Chhu river, built around a large rock where Guru Rinpoche meditated. The temple is famous for its annual festival that attracts pilgrims from Bhutan and neighboring regions. The site is considered highly sacred and is believed to have special healing powers.

placesToVisit.name: Kulong Chhu River
placesToVisit.description: The Kulong Chhu River flows through Trashiyangtse district and provides beautiful scenery and opportunities for nature activities. The river is surrounded by pristine forests and supports diverse wildlife. Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, observe local wildlife, and experience the natural beauty of eastern Bhutan.

placesToVisit.name: Yangtse Village
placesToVisit.description: Yangtse is the main village of the district and serves as a center for traditional crafts and culture. The village is known for its skilled artisans who produce traditional woodcarvings, textiles, and other handicrafts. Visitors can explore the village, interact with local craftsmen, and learn about traditional techniques that have been passed down through generations.

placesToVisit.name: Doksum Village
placesToVisit.description: Doksum is a traditional village known for its beautiful mountain setting and traditional way of life. The village offers visitors a chance to experience authentic rural Bhutanese culture and traditional customs. Visitors can stay with local families, participate in traditional activities, and enjoy the peaceful mountain environment.

usps: Center for traditional Bhutanese woodcarving

name: Gasa Dzongkhag
description: Bhutan's northernmost district, known for its high-altitude landscapes and ancient fortress.

placesToVisit.name: Gasa Dzong
placesToVisit.description: Gasa Dzong, built in the 17th century, is one of the most remote and strategically important dzongs in Bhutan. Located at an altitude of 2,800 meters, the dzong guards the northern border and serves as the administrative center of the district. The dzong offers spectacular views of the surrounding Himalayan peaks and is accessible only by trekking. It houses important religious artifacts and serves as the venue for the annual Gasa Tshechu festival.

placesToVisit.name: Gasa Hot Springs (Gasa Tshachu)
placesToVisit.description: Gasa Hot Springs are natural thermal springs located near Gasa Dzong, believed to have medicinal properties that can cure various ailments. The hot springs are a popular destination for both locals and trekkers who come to relax and rejuvenate after long treks. The springs are surrounded by beautiful mountain scenery and offer a unique experience of bathing in natural hot water at high altitude.

placesToVisit.name: Laya Village
placesToVisit.description: Laya is one of the highest settlements in Bhutan at 3,800 meters, inhabited by the Layap people who have a unique culture and lifestyle. The village is famous for its distinctive conical bamboo hats worn by women and its yak herding traditions. Visitors can experience the unique highland culture, interact with yak herders, and learn about life at high altitude. The village serves as a base for treks to higher altitudes.

placesToVisit.name: Snowman Trek Base Camp
placesToVisit.description: The Snowman Trek is considered one of the most challenging and spectacular treks in the world, passing through some of Bhutan's most remote and beautiful high-altitude landscapes. The trek offers stunning views of major Himalayan peaks including Gangkar Puensum, the world's highest unclimbed mountain. The base camp area provides access to this legendary trek and offers spectacular mountain views.

placesToVisit.name: Lunana Villages
placesToVisit.description: Lunana is a collection of remote high-altitude villages that represent some of the most isolated communities in Bhutan. The villages are accessible only by trekking and offer visitors a chance to experience traditional highland life unchanged by modern influences. The area is known for its spectacular mountain scenery, traditional yak herding culture, and warm hospitality of the local people.

placesToVisit.name: Thanza Village
placesToVisit.description: Thanza is one of the highest permanently inhabited villages in Bhutan, located at over 4,000 meters altitude. The village is known for its traditional stone houses, yak herding culture, and spectacular mountain views. Visitors can experience life at extreme altitude, interact with local yak herders, and enjoy some of the most pristine mountain scenery in the Himalayas.

placesToVisit.name: Raphstreng Village
placesToVisit.description: Raphstreng is a traditional highland village that serves as a stopping point for trekkers heading to higher altitudes. The village offers insights into traditional highland life and yak herding practices. Visitors can experience authentic mountain culture, interact with local families, and enjoy beautiful mountain views while acclimatizing to high altitude.

placesToVisit.name: Koina Village
placesToVisit.description: Koina is a small highland village that maintains traditional ways of life and ancient customs. The village is surrounded by spectacular mountain scenery and offers visitors a chance to experience authentic highland culture. Visitors can stay with local families, participate in traditional activities, and enjoy the peaceful mountain environment.

usps: Gateway to Bhutan's highest peaks and most challenging treks
